data.content: The components are divided into two modules: Definition and Function
createComponent: Handles both definition and registration of components in a single operation.

• Must be declared as a web-component
  • Generated DOM replaces the component upon rendering
  • Standard naming conventions apply:
    • Start with lowercase letter
    • Must contain a hyphen
The component function executes upon instance creation.

• An array containing all child component definitions
  • Requires dependency loading prior to app initialization

Alternatively, you can use the useComponent utility to load all components once before initializing the app. However, doing so will make it harder to access components via LSP (e.g., Go to Definition) easily.
An array of component states exposed for external access (e.g., parent-to-child communication).

Component State System:
  • All component states derive from the mobCore store
  • Inherits full store functionality (reactivity, etc.)
bindStore: Synchronizes component state with an external mobStore, inheriting its full reactivity system.

Web Component Conversion: When the component function returns its defined tag as the first node, it:
  • Becomes usable as a web component
  • Gains full lifecycle management

Normally, all onMount functions are executed after all components have been created.
Enabling this property will cause the onMount function to execute before the child components are created.

Component Typing System:
  • Associate an interface to define types for:
    • methods
    • states
    • refs

  • Automatic function configuration
    • getRef: Returns HTMLElement
    • getRefs: Returns HTMLElement[]
Type Safety Note: The type parameter (dynamic runtime checks) bypasses TypeScript's static type validation.
Specialized Types: Enables clean component segmentation into focused utility functions.
Reactive management of classes, styles, text, and DOM refs
Event handling for components and shared DOM nodes
Managing a component instance and its methods
Managing DOM node updates, reactive collections, and on-the-fly component generation
Specialized components, slot patterns, and web component support
Managing classes directly on component instances ( non reactive )
